item.title: Send Custom Email from Subversion Commits Tutorial
item.author: bray@sent.com (Brian Ray)
item.content:encoded:
I wrote this script to accomplish the following:


  • use an external SMTP email server
  • Use Python
  • Not use the svn.fs packages form subversion
  • Allow configuration on a reg-ex pattern
  • Send the logs and diffs in the email
  • allow simply dropping the script into svn/hooks/post-commit


First, I tried the contrib scripts from subversion. They were a little too complicated and had dependencies I did not want to install on a shared server.

I wrote this script to accomplish the goals.

Here are some links to the script:

  • Plain source
  • Colorized source


Or here is the source inline:
Continue reading "Send Custom Email from Subversion Commits Tutorial"

item.title: ChiPy Video Posted / Looking for advice
item.author: bray@sent.com (Brian Ray)
item.content:encoded:
(I also posted this question to the ChiPy List)

I posted the video and will be reposting a better quality version soon
if some of you can help me work out the details (Disclaimer: I am
totally new to recording and publishing video). If you can't wait here
is the first try:



Link to Video

Admittedly, the quality is poor on my first try. The aspect ratio I
shot in was different than how I posted to Google Video--so its skewed
to letterbox. The video looks and sounds much better on my computer
before I post. I shot the video in HD widescreen and went to mp4 the
way the google video suggests in its FAQ. I am not sure I like the
quality of any of the videos on a hosted web viewer solution versus
the pod-casts I view through iTunes. But, I am also concerned if
other pod-cast readers are readily available (Linux? Windows?) so that
all of you viewing can use any feed I produce.

If everyone can use this format, I would like to explore the option of
using the mv4 format in the form of a podcast. IE, it would be nice to
have a RSS feed just for meetings. I did see a Python package called
PyRSS2Gen http://www.dalkescientific.com/Python/PyRSS2Gen.html. Does
anybody know the correlation between the content of the RSS entry for
video and the example used on this website? For instance, is the
content of each entry just html pointing to the video data as a
hyperlink? What do I need to consider if I want to optimize for
devices like the iPhone and iPod?

Also, the video is kind of large in the mv4 or mp4 formats. Its like
around 400-600Meg for 1 hour with the compressions I have available on
my platform. Also, the video when digitized from the HD format takes
60 Gigs. So, I do not really want to save the original data on disk.
Also, I do not really want to host the data in the mv4 or mp4 formats
on the ChiPy Server. Its just a lot of disk space and bandwidth. What
other options do I have. Can I use a file hosting service in
conjunction with a link from a RSS feed I do host on ChiPy Server?

Someone else suggested a torrent. I am not sure how this works either.

Like I mentioned before, I am a novice and do want to continue
recording and sharing this information online. Any suggestions or
advice? I am looking forward to learning but do not know where to start.

item.title: Django "newforms" review: I like it
item.author: bray@sent.com (Brian Ray)
item.content:encoded:
After taking some time off from Django, I have returned and am happy with what I found--in particular "newforms."

The thing I like about Django is it seems to continue to move forward despite some drastic swings in loyal users and a API changes. When a open source project starts to get some attention, I have often found that the projects goal get lost in the clutter by persons involved with mixed motives. The project tear apart in a way not repairable. The project becomes a sort of a Humpty Dumpty. I can tell that by newforms the project continues on track. Yes, its anouther big change for those who can't wait for 1.0, but they seemed to pull it off.

"newforms" is like the removal of a thorn from Django side. The old way of handling forms was one of the things I did not like about Django. It seemed too clumsy. Nevertheless, the newforms method of modeling the intent of a form and then providing a form in table or list item format is fabulous. newforms method of self generation from models is brilliant. The error handling and the round tripping of data is great. "newforms" provides the instant gratification I needed for the one-off project I had to produce under time constraints.

item.title: Is picking YAML a bad thing?
item.author: bray@sent.com (Brian Ray)
item.content:encoded:
A Python/C++ project I am working on requires a lightweight human readable/writable markup. Unless you stop me, I am about to pick YAML...


Continue reading "Is picking YAML a bad thing?"

item.title: I pick Komodo, for now
item.author: bray@sent.com (Brian Ray)
item.content:encoded:
I have been shopping for a more IDE-like Python programming environment. I typically have stuck with VIM. But now I have been working with wxPython and more event-driven stuff where I really want things like: breakpoints, debugging, code-complete, code-folding, and other IDE niceties. Its not that I can not accomplish the same thing with VIM, its that it was much easier with Komodo.

I can not say its been an easy, however. So far...

Continue reading "I pick Komodo, for now"

item.title: Python Bootcamp taught David Beazley
item.author: bray@sent.com (Brian Ray)
item.content:encoded:
Trolling for Python news, I ran across this article Make Your Pilgrimage to Python Bootcamp at the Big Nerd Ranch, November 5-9, 2007. It states that the class teaches, "using Python to process data, creating links between existing applications, and creating complex mission critical applications involving concurrency, network programming, and distributed systems." Better yet, the class will be thought by David Beazley, one of the great Python Guru's also from Chicago. Seems to be a really good choice for Big Nerd Ranch Class. Here is the complete press release:


Continue reading "Python Bootcamp taught David Beazley"

item.title: Python 3000: Small changes that matter
item.author: bray@sent.com (Brian Ray)
item.content:encoded:
This is partially in response to Chris', Why Python 3k Shouldnâ€™t Be Ruby (and a mention of Erlang) and my investigation on what I see Python 3000 as being, in plain English.

First, none of the changes in Python 3000 are so Earth-shattering that one should fear being taken in the wrong direction. As part of the Python tradition, the PEP (Python Enhancement Proposal) process is in full effect for Python 3000. I believe its name, "Python 3000," comes from the fact that the PEP index has all Python 3k proposals between 3000-3999. I have highlighted some of these below for others to comment. Consider this my executive-and-check-if-I-am-understanding-things-summary. Likewise, if you take his short list as the major changes, along with the arrangement of items in the std lib, there really is not too much here to grasp.


Continue reading "Python 3000: Small changes that matter"

item.title: ChiPy August Roundup: TextMate, AdrBook2Gmail
item.author: bray@sent.com (Brian Ray)
item.content:encoded:
The Snakes on Apples meeting went well. Attendance was just under 30, from what I could tell. Good for this time of year and for a topic that may not interest everyone. About half were regulars, 1/4 in from out of town to attend the C4, and others were new or students from UIC.





Kumar McMillan gave a detailed presentation on TextMate. I talked about my new AdrBook2Gmail plug in written in Python.
Continue reading "ChiPy August Roundup: TextMate, AdrBook2Gmail"

item.title: AdrBook2Gmail Sources Released
item.author: bray@sent.com (Brian Ray)
item.content:encoded: I have released the sources (found here) for the my AdrBook2Gmail plugin. Its goal is to plug into Mac OSX address book to sync to and from gmail contacts in an intelligent manner. A gmail account and a modern Mac is required. There also exists a installer if you simply want to test--but be warned its not fully functional or even close. This project is still very much in development right now. So this is a alpha / pre-alpha release. A new BSD style license has already been applied. I will present on this project at tonights ChiPy meeting tonight. I am open to hearing suggestions you may have on where to take this next. I think the concept is good, but the needs some work; aka, finished. Also, the data structures describing what consists of a Contact are realized on both ends. Likewise, the way a contact may mash together, is fairly well along. Let me know your thoughts.

item.title: ChiPy Snakes on Apples
item.author: bray@sent.com (Brian Ray)
item.content:encoded: I am organizing this months ChiPy Meeting titled Snakes on Apples http://chipy.org/SnakesOnApples. Its a meeting about developing Python on the Mac. We have free food, a great new venue University of Illinois at Chicago (UIC), and some great presentations lined up; which reminds me I need to finish my presentation. See you all there.

item.title: JavaFX this summer
item.author: bray@sent.com (Brian Ray)
item.content:encoded: For the three or so projects I have been putting off until after finals, I finally can say I may be able to consider thinking about actually finishing these. So, to start I am scraping off the blog-sphere trying to get caught up on the latest and greatest. For the website I have hesitated publishing, yeah the one concerning real estate search and rescue I had everyone so excited about, we talked about adding AJAX functionality to the UI. So, now, what is the JavaFX and should I be looking at JavaFX instead of AJAX? And, finally, when are we coming out with PythonFX?

item.title: Zenoss Core SourceForge's Project of the month
item.author: bray@sent.com (Brian Ray)
item.content:encoded:
Zenoss Core is SF project of the month. Wow. This is nice to see. Because:


  1. I am getting tired of WebMin
  2. its written in Python
  3. it's something liked by Sys Admin people and its not written Perl
  4. its broken up into layers user, data, and collection (presumably MVC like)
  5. it looks all slick and web2.0 like
  6. its written in Python


Although, things I am note as sure about:


  1. is it proven
  2. is it as robust
  3. why zope
  4. why only mysql
  5. is it as secure (recalling recent WebMin exploits)




Continue reading "Zenoss Core SourceForge's Project of the month"

item.title: Life without ChiPy
item.author: bray@sent.com (Brian Ray)
item.content:encoded:
I blame myself, really. This is for this month's ChiPy meeting that never happened. It like the second ChiPy meeting we canceled since May 2005 or something like that. I posted to the forum we should instead just meet at a pub, but no takers. I guess everyone is too busy planning our bid for PyCon or playing with their new toys


So instead, I thought I would grab the oldest version of Python I could find, and see if it would compile on my Mac OSX 10.4.5. Yep:

$ ./Python/python 
Python 1.0.1 (Jan 11 2007)
Copyright 1991-1994 Stichting Mathematisch Centrum, Amsterdam
>>> print "hi"
hi
>>> 1+1
2
>>> 1/0
Traceback (innermost last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1
ZeroDivisionError: integer division or modulo
See, its not that I have no life, its that I schedule time for not having a life.
Continue reading "Life without ChiPy"

item.title: SVN to ICAL
item.author: bray@sent.com (Brian Ray)
item.content:encoded:
I started using Subversion for my own home consulting business. This brings a whole new feeling to the already great version control system over the other repositories I have used with dozens of committers. I decided to make a little hack that ties together :

  • Version Control (SVN)
  • Project Management (ICAL)
  • Billing (email log)


All in Python, course! My little nifty script source found below.


Continue reading "SVN to ICAL"
